courseDescription: Students will learn concepts and theories of interpersonal relationships.  Development of skills necessary for effective communication will be stressed.
Students will learn about human services, the helping process, and the role and function of the human service worker.  Students will be exposed to local and state human services facilities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of local and state human services facilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in the context of human services
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and applying relevant laws and regulations

courseDescription: Presents theories and techniques used by human services workers in a variety of settings.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of practical techniques used in various settings
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborative work with other human services professionals
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in a human services context

courseDescription: Focuses on career development throughout the life span with emphasis on vocational theories, interventions, assessments, and socioeconomic factors.

This course serves as an introduction to multicultural helping.  The influence of socio-identities (e.g., race, ethnicity, religion, gender, socioeconomic status, sexual orientation) on individuals' functioning, concerns, and the helping process will be explored.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of socio-identity influence on individual functioning
Identification and understanding of diversity concerns

courseTitle: Case Management & Crisis Techniques through Field Observation
courseDescription: Students will visit and examine human services systems such as mental health, substance abuse, criminal justice, education, rehabilitation, and professional associations to facilitate decision-making in selecting an internship and to gain a complex understanding of the roles of the human services professional.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of substance abuse, mental health, criminal justice, education, rehabilitation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with professionals in various fields
Adapting communication style to different professional settings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Assessing and understanding organizational structures in human services

courseDescription: Individual study under the supervision of an undergraduate faculty member.

This course presents models and practices in evaluating, monitoring, and implementing human services programs.  The course includes an overview of funding, creating budgets and monitoring expenditures for programs. This is an upper-level writing intensive class. A grade of C or better is required.
This course combines lectures and experiential learning about psycho-educational groups.  Principles and practices for developing and leading psycho-educational groups are emphasized.

This course develops the professional identity of the student as a practitioner of substance abuse services while introducing the student to the signs and symptoms of substance abuse, the recovery process and relapse prevention methods.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding signs and symptoms of substance abuse
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy towards individuals with substance abuse
Communication with individuals undergoing recovery process

courseDescription: This course provides an overview of how human service workers assist children in a variety of settings.  Emphasis will be placed upon advocacy, supportive work, and short term crisis intervention.
This course explores effective crisis intervention, examines prevention strategies, and develops students' ethical decision making within human service practice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of ethical decision-making processes in human service practice

courseDescription: This course explores effective substance abuse treatment planning and intervention strategies through lectures and experiential learning and examines research trends in the substance abuse field.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching trends in substance abuse field

courseDescription: This course involves field placement in a human services setting. Approximately 400 hours are devoted to field placement, group seminars and individual supervision.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of digital tools for coordination and communication
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a professional setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing complex situations in a human services setting
Developing and implementing solutions to human services challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in a human services context

courseDescription: This course provides a study of the family as a system and an introduction to a variety of issues confronting the family, including child abuse, substance abuse and addiction, spouse abuse, and others that produce more than usual stress in the family. Available community resources for helping families will be examined.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying signs of abuse and addiction

courseTitle: Entrepreneurship in Human Services and Non-Profit Fundraising
courseDescription: This course is designed to expose human service students to the art of ethical fund-raising in human services, including annual and capital campaigns, telemarketing, special events, direct mail marketing, face-to-face solicitation, e-fund-raising, and grant writing. This course replaced HMSV 441. Students with credit for HMSV 441 cannot receive credit toward their degree for HMSV 494.
